hypothesis_content.title: Asymmetric Volatility Expansion on 'More Downside' News
hypothesis_content.statement: When BTC is in a NEUTRAL regime and news headlines explicitly cite technical or fundamental reasons for 'more downside' (e.g., '5 Reasons... Why More Downside Is Possible'), and BTC is trading within 3% of a major, widely-watched support level (e.g., prior weekly low, 50-day MA), implied volatility (BTC DVOL or ATM options IV) will rise disproportionately more for puts than for calls over the next 36 hours, creating a skew expansion trade opportunity.
hypothesis_content.rationale: In neutral regimes near key support, fear-based narratives can disproportionately impact option pricing before spot price moves materially. The news catalyst amplifies the perceived risk of a breakdown, causing option dealers to hedge by demanding higher premiums for downside protection (puts), widening the skew. This is a 'fear premium' capture trade.
entry_conditions: News headline analysis detects explicit 'more downside' narrative with technical/fundamental reasoning
BTC price within 3% of a major defined support level (pre-defined list)
Current 25-delta put-call IV spread is within its 10-day historical range (not already extreme)

exit_conditions.take_profit: 25-delta put-call IV spread expands by 5 volatility points (e.g., from 2 to 7)
exit_conditions.stop_loss: BTC price breaks decisively above the resistance level defined as 5% above the entry price, invalidating the downside fear

hypothesis_content.falsification_criteria: The median IV skew expansion in qualifying scenarios is less than 2 volatility points.
